image.altText: An aerial image looking down on a number of canoes around rocks on the edge of a fast-moving river.

props.synopsis: A 65-year-old Lithuanian man remains in a critical condition after being trapped and partially submerged in the Franklin River for 20 hours. Medical crews amputated the man's left leg to free him.Â

title.children: Man who had leg amputated in Franklin River rescue in critical condition

image.altText: University of Tasmania logo on clothing.

props.synopsis: A few years ago, the University of Tasmania proposed about 1,200 dwellings including medium-rise apartment buildings above its Sandy Bay campus. It sparked a furious response â€” but the land is back on the agenda.

title.children: A university in need of cash, a city in need of housing. Is parliament about to grant UTAS's wishes?

image.altText: Woman helping a man using a wheelchair into a van.

props.synopsis: When Taraidh became quadriplegic 18 months ago, it turned his family's emergency plans on their head. A new program is helping equip people like him with the tools they need to prepare.

title.children: 'It will save lives': Disaster emergency preparedness workshops offered for Tasmanians with disability in pilot project

image.altText: Large Aboriginal flag flying on city street with crowd in background

props.synopsis: For some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, receiving an Australian of the Year award can be used to draw attention to important issues. But others feel unable to accept a nomination because the timing of the awards is too painful.

title.children: 'Not an easy decision': Many First Nations people are conflicted about Australian of the Year Awards

image.altText: a woman uses large hedge trimmers to tidy up a box hedge next to another woman standing in front of a rose bush.

props.synopsis: Nestled within the walls of the world heritage-listed Woolmers Estate sits Tasmania's largest rose collection. The sprawling 1.5 hectare garden is largely maintained by about a dozen volunteers.

title.children: These volunteers care for Tasmania's largest rose garden. Here's their tips and tricks

image.altText: Teisha Archer's son Anders, Bruny Island

props.synopsis: Parents in this island community, which has no child care services, were "very excited" when an early learning trial for three-year-olds was promised by 2024. Now, with no progress made on delivering that, parents want answers.

title.children: On this island there's no childcare and a promised early learning initiative is behind schedule

image.altText: A man in an orange high vis vest in a fish processing factory.

props.synopsis: A study last year identified a sardine population stretching from NSW's south coast to Tasmania could rival the biggest fishery in Australia â€” and there's a push to make use of it.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ 'Exceeded our predictions': Potentially one of the largest fisheries in Australia is sitting offshore, untapped

image.altText: Nathan Lyon holds his hand on his head while Usman Khawaja and Marnus Labuschagne stand nearby

props.synopsis: A champion Australian team may have had visions of glorious Ashes farewells next summer, but as India continues to make the hosts look second rate in Perth, those plans may need a dramatic rethink.

title.children: The end of an era is approaching for Australian cricket. Its best laid plans may need to be ripped up

image.altText: O'Neil and Albanese walk through the lower house chamber, looking serious.

props.synopsis: Two housing proposals will be put to a vote this week without a deal to seem them made law. It will be the last chance before the election for the government's proposals to co-purchase homes with first homebuyers, and offer tax incentives for developers to build more affordable rental apartments.

title.children: Housing supports to be put to vote without a deal, after Greens compromise rejected

image.altText: A woman voting at night at a cardboard polling booth

props.synopsis: The era of Baby Boomers as the dominant voting force in Australian politics is at an end and the impact will play out at the next federal election. If you listen carefully, you can already hear that politicians know the power and numbers have shifted to younger people.

title.children: Farewell Baby Boomers as Gen Z and Millennials become Australia's key voting force

image.altText: A graphic showing a hand holding a wallet with money, and icons representing bills, shopping and a house.

props.synopsis: Millions of Australians are barely getting by financially, according to polling for the ABC's Q+A. And they give little credit to the federal government for helping out.

title.children: Australians are financially stressed, questioning government help, Q+A/YouGov poll finds

image.altText: A voter puts a Senate paper into a ballot box for the 2016 federal election.

props.synopsis: Labor says its proposal is about getting big money out of politics, but crossbenchers and Clive Palmer say they are shutting out competitors.

title.children: A 2022 election rewind shows Labor's proposed funding shake-up would affect Teals, Palmer the most

image.altText: Printed photo of a young girl and boy playing with action figures.

props.synopsis: Georgy Sides and her friendsÂ grew up with absent fathers who served their country in Afghanistan in the wake of September 11. Now they're sharing their stories of how Australia's commitment to a distant theatre of war altered their adolescence and shaped who they are today.

title.children: 'Trained to be sociopaths': Having a dad in the SAS shaped relationships in these families

image.altText: Sione Tuipulotu scores a try for Scotland against the Wallabies.

props.synopsis: The Wallabies will rue poor defence and a lack of discipline in their defeat to Scotland, but they're not a lost cause under the guidance of coach Joe Schmidt, writes Luke Pentony.

title.children: Wallabies did themselves no favours in defeat to Scotland but there's light at the end of the tunnel

image.altText: A Qantas plane on the tarmac.

props.synopsis: Sky-high airfares, poor flight times and unexpected scheduling changes have become standard in Darwin â€” and there are concerns prices may be about to climb even higher.Â

title.children: 'They abandoned us years ago': Qantas and Virgin accused of price gouging in NT capital

image.altText: An image of an iPhone saying the internet isn't working. The woman holding the phone is on a seat on a Sydney train.

props.synopsis:
Imagine no Instagram scrolling, no watching Netflix, no checking emails and no jumping on a work video call. Many commuters are wondering why their phone reception is so poor when on trains.

Â

title.children: Commuters have limited phone reception when on Sydney trains. Here's what the telcos had to say

image.altText: Bali Nine pair, Si Yi Chen and Matthew Norman, sit staring at the camera

props.synopsis: The prison doctor at Kerobokan jail, who spoke with prisoners Matthew Norman and Si Yi Chen on Saturday, says they are "hopeful but anxious" following a deal between Jakarta and Canberra to allow the remaining so-called Bali Nine prisoners to finish their jail terms in Australia.

title.children: 'Hopeful but anxious': Bali Nine prisoner cries tears of joy after news of possible return to Australia

image.altText: Zvi Kogan a man in glasses with a long beard.

props.synopsis: Rabbi Kogan who worked for an Orthodox Jewish group called Chabad, vanished in Dubai on Thursday.

title.children: Three arrested over alleged murder of Israeli rabbi in UAE

image.altText: People stand around debris on the ground.

props.synopsis: The Israeli military has issued new evacuation orders to residents in areas of an eastern Gaza City suburb, setting off a new wave of displacement on Sunday.

title.children: Israeli army orders Gaza City suburb evacuated, fires rockets at Lebanon army centre

image.altText: Red Bull driver Max Verstappen punches his fists and screams with excitement

props.synopsis: The mark of a true F1 great is not what you can do when you have the best car. It is how you can overcome setbacks to win â€” just like Verstappen in 2024.Â

title.children: Max Verstappen joins the exclusive list of all-time F1 greats with a fourth world title â€” and this was his best

image.altText: A man wearing a white shirt learning against a football post and holding a football.

props.synopsis: NRL took its toll on PJ Marsh's body. Fourteen years after retirement, he's suffering the long-term consequences and fears for young players who aren't educated on the risks of knocks to the head.

title.children: Former NRL star battling mood swings, memory loss joins call for mandatory concussion training

image.altText: Side-by-side photos of Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles, two Melbourne teens who have been hospitalised in Thailand

props.synopsis: Mark Jones says the government of Laos cannot let his daughter's death be in vain, after the 19-year-old girl fell ill and died from methanol poisoning.

title.children: Bianca Jones's father pleads to not let teenager's death be in vain, urges government action on methanol poisoning

image.altText: DUPLICATE - meta accounts

props.synopsis: Laws that would force social media companies to police misinformation and outright lies on their platform have been formally abandoned by the federal government. Laws to restrict gambling advertising will also not proceed this year.Â

title.children: Laws to regulate misinformation online abandoned, gambling advertising ban pushed to next year

image.altText: Sun setting on large housing development.

props.synopsis: One of Australia's largest developers says it has paused work on a major housing estate after delays meant contracts had to be cancelled.

title.children: 'Distress and financial strain' as developer signed on buyers without approvals in place

image.altText: A group of fire ants floating on floodwaters.

props.synopsis: Experts say riverbank infestations of fire ants are exploding south of Brisbane, and there's a risk the venomous pests could spread further through flooding.

title.children: Thousands of fire ant nests found along Logan River, with fears heavy rainfall could help them spread

image.altText: Daizy Gedeon organiser Hands off Lebanon

props.synopsis: The Hands Off Lebanon event in Sydney's west calls on the Australian government to stand up for Lebanonâ€™s sovereignty.Â

title.children: 'Enough is enough': Lebanese community mourns victims of Israeli attacks

image.altText: Sara Duterte wearing a green dress behind a brown lectern topped with pink flowers in front of a Philippine flag

props.synopsis: Sara Duterte held an early press conference to announce she had directed someone to kill Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, his wife and the speaker of the House.

title.children: Sara Duterte holds press conference to say she directed assassin to kill Philippine president

image.altText: A man wearing a checked shirt standing in a vineyard.

props.synopsis: At Mount Majura Vineyard on the edge of Canberra, viticulturalist James Hopper is planting new grape varieties that can better cope with the effects of a changing climate.Â

title.children: 'Harvesting up to 40 days earlier': Winemakers look to new varieties to cope with warming climate

image.altText: A crowd of activists holding white protest placards wite one person dressed in black, centre, pointing upwards

props.synopsis: The deal among COP29 nations will mean that richer countries lead the payments to support nations adapting to the impacts of climate change.

title.children: COP29 agrees on $460 billion funding deal to help nations adapt to climate change

image.altText: An image of a phone with social media app logos floating around it

props.synopsis: As senators gather to discuss the federal government's planned social media ban for under-16s, some young people feel the bill will reduce harm but negatively impact their ability to communicate.

title.children: Young Australians weigh in on under-16 social media ban as senators meet over plan

image.altText: A  large power plant blowing smoke with green rolling hills in the foreground.

props.synopsis: This year marks a century since coal mined at Yallourn was first used to supply Melbourne, and in Victoria's coal country there is still a nostalgia for the good old days.

title.children: Coal nostalgia remains as Latrobe Valley looks to future beyond power generation

image.altText: Two young girls laying on carpet each with a serious expression and looking at a tablet.

props.synopsis: Children are likely to look to the adults around them to gauge how they should respond to distressing stories in the news. To help, adults should begin by checking their own emotional pulse, these experts say.

title.children: News is hard to avoid, even for kids. Here's how adults can help them consume it more healthily

image.altText: Photo of teenage boy spinning a trolley around on an empty basketball court. He wears an orange t-shirt and cap.

props.synopsis: South Australian artist Emmaline Zanelli wanted to understand what life was like for young people in a remote desert mining town. So she took a bunch of cameras and went to meet the young people living there.

title.children: Stunning footage captures life for teenagers living next door to one of Australia's largest mines
